questions.text: Match the following clinical conditions with tuberculosis of different regions in the body:
questions.solution:
Shoulder Joint Tuberculosis:

  • May not produce pus and is termed 'caries sicca.'
  • Should be considered in the differential diagnosis of 'frozen shoulder,' which is a more common shoulder problem.

Spina Ventosa:

  • Refers to tuberculosis of the phalanges of the hand.
  • Affected phalanx swells up like a balloon.

Triple Deformity in TB Knee:

  • Characterized by:
    • Flexion of the knee
    • External or lateral rotation of the tibia
    • Posterior subluxation of the knee
  • Treatment includes antitubercular drugs, with possible replacement or arthrodesis.

Spinal Tuberculosis:

  • Most Common site of TB(paradiscal involvement)
  • Also known as Pott's disease.

Hip Tuberculosis

  • Mc site Acetabulum
  • 2nd most common site for TB

Key takeaways

  • TB shoulder - Dry sicca
  • TB spine - Pott's disease
  • TB phalanges - Spina ventosa
  • TB Knee - Triple Deformity

choices.text: Commonly seen in the dorso-lumbar region specifically in the T12-L1 junction
Most common sequelae of TB spine is fibrous ankylosis
Hong Kong operation is done in TB spine
Acute onset and sudden progression are poor prognostic features in Pott's paraplegia

questions.text: Select false statement in view of tuberculosis of spine:
questions.solution:
TB Spine

Common Affected Area: Most commonly affects the dorsolumbar region, particularly the T12-L1 junction. (Option A)

Earliest Feature: Pain is the initial symptom.

Initial Impact: Affects the vertebral body first.

Associated Condition: Tuberculosis with polyarthritis is known as Poncet's disease.

Surgical Procedure: The Hong Kong operation is performed in cases of tuberculosis. (Option C)

Poor Prognostic Factors in Pott's Paraplegia: (Option D)

  • Acute onset
  • Sudden progression
  • Long-standing paraplegia

Common Sequelae: Bony ankylosis is a frequent outcome. (Option B)

Key takeaways

  • Healing of TB arthritis occurs by fibrous ankylosis.
  • Most common sequelae of TB spondylitis is bony ankylosis.

choices.text: Paradiscal is the commonest type of vertebral TB
TB spine is always secondary and occurs due to hematogenous spread

questions.text: Tuberculosis of spine - All of these statements are true except:
questions.solution:
Kyphosis is commonly seen in later stages of TB spine and not scoliosis.

Types of Vertebral Tuberculosis

  1. Paradiscal:
    • Description: Most common type.
    • Affected Areas: Contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the intervening disc.
  2. Central:
    • Description: Affects the body of a single vertebra.
    • Impact: Leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra; nearby disc may remain normal.
    • Collapse Types:
      • Wedging: More common.
      • Concertina: Less common.
  3. Anterior:
    • Description: Infection is localized to the anterior part of the vertebral body.
    • Spread: Moves up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  4. Posterior:
    • Description: Affects the posterior complex of the vertebra.
    • Affected Areas: Pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process.

Option A: In late stages, a significant part or whole of the vertebral body may be destroyed, leading to angular kyphotic deformity. (Option A)

Option B: TB spine patients can develop a psoas abscess. As it tracks down the inguinal canal it causes flexion deformity of the hip. As this deformity is not due to hip pathology but due to spine pathology, it is called pseudo flexion deformity of the hip.

Option C: Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.

Option D: TB of the spine is always secondary. The bacteria reach the spine via the haematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.

Key takeaways:

TB Spine:

  • Secondary via hematogenous route
  • Mc Paradiscal
  • Causes Pseudo Flexion deformities of hip
  • Causes Kyphosis in later stages.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual developed discharging sinus after a chronic treatment for a fracture. His x-rays shows sequestrum formation due to chronic osteomyelitis. Identify the cause of chronic OM.
questions.solution:
The above image is showing ring sequestrum which is seen in external fixators.

Sequestrum and Involucrum in Bone Infections

Sequestrum

  • Definition: A sequestrum is a piece of dead bone that has become separated from the living bone due to an infection, typically in the context of osteomyelitis.
  • Appearance:
    • The sequestrum appears pale.
    • It has a smooth inner surface and a rough outer surface.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • The outer surface is rough because it is continuously eroded by surrounding infected granulation tissue. This granulation tissue is the body's attempt to "eat away" or remove the dead bone (sequestrum).

Involucrum

  • Definition: An involucrum is the layer of new bone growth that forms around a sequestrum.
  • Characteristics:
    • It is dense and sclerotic, providing a protective layer over the sequestrum.
    • The involucrum may develop holes, known as cloacae , through which pus can drain from the infected site.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • The bony cavities within the involucrum are lined with infected granulation tissue, which continues to be involved in the inflammatory and healing process.

Incorrect options-

Option A: Tuberculosis Shows Sandy Sequestrum in chronic OM.

Option B: Perthes disease shows Coralliform sequestrum in Chronic OM.

Option C: Amputation stumps shows Crown Sequestrum in Chronic OM.

questions.text:
The pathognomonic sign of chronic OM is persistent discharging sinus. Identify the suitable cause for this feature of this condition. (multiple correct options)
A. Resistance to antibiotics
B. Inadequate follow up and treatment
C. Sequestrum
D. Reduced blood supply in affected bone
questions.solution:
Pathology of Osteomyelitis

Progression from Acute to Chronic Osteomyelitis

Acute osteomyelitis commonly progresses to chronic osteomyelitis due to several factors:

  1. Delayed and Inadequate Treatment (Option B)
    • Cause: Delay in treatment allows pus to spread within the medullary cavity and subperiosteally.
    • Consequences:
      • Death of bone tissue, leading to sequestrum formation. (Option C)
      • Destruction of cancellous bone creates cavities within the bone.
      • Persistent infection due to "non-collapsing" bone cavities and sequestra.
  2. Type and Virulence of Organism
    • Cause: Highly virulent organisms may not be controlled even with early and adequate treatment.
    • Consequences:
      • Persistent infection despite effective initial treatment.
  3. Reduced Host Resistance
    • Cause: Malnutrition or compromised defense mechanisms.
    • Consequences:
      • Persistent infection due to weakened body defenses.

Key takeaways:

Acute osteomyelitis commonly progresses to chronic osteomyelitis due to

  • Delayed and inadequate treatment
  • Type and virulence of organism
  • Reduced host resistance

Option A and D: they are not directly related to chronic pus discharge.

choices.text: Global increase in range of motion
The acetabulum is eroded and destroyed
A sequel to septic arthritis of hip in infancy

questions.text: All of the following are salient features of Tom-Smith arthritis except:
questions.solution:
Sequelae of Septic Arthritis of the Hip in Infants (tom smith arthritis)

  • Description:
    • This condition results from septic arthritis of the hip in infants. (Option D)
    • The head of the femur, which is cartilaginous at this age, is rapidly and completely destroyed by the pyogenic process.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Onset:
      • Acute with rapid abscess formation.
      • The abscess may burst or be incised and typically heals quickly.
      • Often mistaken for a superficial infection.
      • The child may later present with a limp, but usually without pain.
    • Examination Findings:
      • Unstable gait.
      • Affected leg is shorter.
      • Increased hip movements in all directions. (Option B)
      • Positive telescopy test. (Option A)
    • Radiological Findings:
      • X-ray reveals complete absence of the head and neck of the femur. (Option C)
  • Differentiation from Congenital Dislocation of the Hip (CDH):
    • Clinical Similarities:
      • Both conditions can present around the same age.
    • Differentiating Features:
      • In this condition, the acetabulum is normally developed and round.
      • In CDH, the acetabulum is shallow.
      • Complete absence of the femoral head and neck distinguishes this condition from CDH.
    • Treatment - On the lines of any other arthritis.

Key takeaways:

In Tom Smith arthritis, The head of the femur, which is cartilaginous, is rapidly and completely destroyed by the pyogenic process.

Telescopy test is positive in

  • Fracture NOF non-union
  • DDH
  • Tom Smith arthritis
  • Old neglected posterior hip dislocation

choices.text: Redness and warmth over middle finger

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, swelling, throbbing pain and inability to move the left middle finger. WBC counts, ESR and CRP were raised. X Ray was normal but USG showed findings suggestive of flexor tendon tenosynovitis. The mainstay of clinical examination will be:
questions.solution:
Kanavel's Signs in Suppurative Tenosynovitis

Suppurative tenosynovitis is an infection of the flexor tendon sheath of the fingers. (Option B) Kanavel's signs are a set of clinical features used to diagnose this condition. They are indicative of infection within the tendon sheath and require prompt medical attention. The key signs given above in image

Management:

  • Emergency Treatment:
    • Intravenous (IV) Antibiotics:
      • Immediate administration of IV antibiotics is essential to combat the infection. The choice of antibiotic may be guided by the suspected or confirmed pathogen and its antibiotic sensitivity.
    • Debridement and Washout:
      • In cases where the infection is severe or if there is a collection of pus, surgical intervention may be required. This involves debridement (removal of infected tissue) and washout (irrigation) of the tendon sheath to clear the infection and prevent further tissue damage.

Option A - Redness can be seen in all infections and hence is not specific for tenosynovitis.

Option C - Durkan's test is the most specific test for carpal tunnel syndrome.

Option D - Piano key sign is for DRUJ instability. (distal radio ulnar joint instability)

Key takeaway:

Kanavel's signs which is typically seen in suppurative tenosynovitis of fingers includes following features

  • The finger is swollen (fusiform) throughout its length
  • Acutely tender over the flexor tendon sheath
  • Finger is held in semi-flexed position, and
  • Active or passive extension at the interphalangeal joint is painful.

questions.text: A mother brings her 5-year-old kid with high grade fever with chills. The child has severe pain in right hip and is unable to move the lower limb. On palpation there is fullness of scarpa's triangle. IOC in this condition?
questions.solution:
Clinical Presentation of Septic Arthritis (Pediatric Case)

Investigations:

Radiological Examination:

  • X-ray Findings (early stages):
    • May appear normal
    • Possible increased joint space and soft tissue shadow (due to swelling)
  • X-ray Findings (later stages):
    • Narrowing of joint space
    • Irregular joint margins
    • Potential subluxation or dislocation of the joint
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting effusion, especially in deep joints (e.g., hip, shoulder). Can guide joint aspiration.
  • MRI: May be useful in low grade infections. (Option A)

Laboratory Findings:

  • Blood Tests:
    • Neutrophilic leukocytosis
    • Elevated ESR
    • Blood culture may grow the causative organism (Option D)
  • Joint Aspiration:
    • Best and quickest diagnostic method for septic arthritis
    • Fluid shows features of acute septic inflammation
    • Gram stain provides early clues to the causative organism before culture results are available

Option A: MRI May be useful in low grade infections. However Septic arthritis diagnosed with USG guided Aspiration.

Option B: Joint aspiration is the quickest and the best method of diagnosing septic arthritis. The fluid may show features of acute septic inflammation. USG guided aspiration is the IOC. USG Alone won't suffice.

Option D: Blood culture may grow the causative organism. However Septic arthritis diagnosed with USG guided Aspiration.

Key takeaways

  • Joint aspiration is the quickest and the best method of diagnosing septic arthritis. The fluid may show features of acute septic inflammation. USG guided aspiration is the IOC.
  • Treatment typically involves joint drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy, guided by culture and sensitivity reports.

questions.text: A mother brings her 7 yr kid with complaints of low grade fever, pain and swelling in the left hip region for 2-3 days. The left lower limb has a FABER attitude with mild decrease in movements. Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A - The child has fever, pain and swelling and FABER deformity. This narrows down the DD towards either septic arthritis or transient synovitis. As the fever is low grade and restriction in movement is mild, transient synovitis becomes the best choice.

Transient Synovitis of the Hip (Observation Hip)

Overview:

  • A non-specific synovitis of the hip commonly seen in children aged 4-8 years.
  • Characterized by painful stiffness of the hip, which typically resolves in 2-3 weeks with rest and analgesics.
  • X-ray and ESR are usually normal.
  • Termed 'observation hip' because it requires careful observation to differentiate from other serious conditions.

Differential Diagnosis:

  1. Early Infective Arthritis: (Option B)
    • May mimic observation hip, particularly in early tuberculosis or septic arthritis.
    • Key differentiating features:
      • High ESR
      • Presence of systemic symptoms (fever, malaise)
      • Persistent signs may require biopsy, especially in regions where tuberculosis is common.
  2. Chronic Synovitis:
    • Mono-articular rheumatoid arthritis can resemble observation hip but persists longer and may have systemic features of rheumatoid disease.
  3. Perthes' Disease: (Option D)
    • In early stages, before X-ray changes are evident, it can resemble transient synovitis.
    • Further follow-up reveals characteristic X-ray changes.
    • The typical findings of advanced burnt out (stage 4) Perthes disease are: femoral head deformity with widening and flattening (coxa plana), proximal femoral neck deformity: coxa magna. "sagging rope sign" (thin sclerotic line running across the femoral neck) indicative of Perthes' disease.

Treatment:

  • Bed rest and analgesics.
  • Recovery usually occurs within a few weeks.

Option A - The child has fever, pain and swelling and FABER deformity. This narrows down the DD towards either septic arthritis or transient synovitis. As the fever is low grade and restriction in movement is mild, transient synovitis becomes the best choice.

Option B - Septic Arthritis Present in 0-5 years with more pronounced sign and symptoms with elevated ESR & CRP.

Option C - Acute OM will present with high grade fever and severe pain with the child looking toxic generally.

Option D: Perthes' Disease - In early stages, before X-ray changes are evident, it can resemble transient synovitis. Further follow-up reveals characteristic X-ray changes indicative of Perthes' disease.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: Apparent lengthening of the lower limb is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Stages of TB of the Hip

Tuberculosis of the hip is clinically divided into three stages based on its progression.

Stage I: Stage of Synovitis

  • Key Features:
    • Effusion into the joint causes the hip to assume a position of flexion, abduction, and external rotation for maximum joint capacity.
    • Deformities of flexion and abduction are subtle and compensated by pelvic tilt.
    • The affected limb appears longer due to the compensatory pelvic tilt (apparent lengthening), though true limb lengths are equal. (Option B)
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • The limb remains in external rotation.
    • Rarely diagnosed at this early stage.
    • Also called the stage of apparent lengthening.

Stage II: Stage of Arthritis

  • Key Features:
    • Articular cartilage involvement leads to muscle spasms, with the more powerful flexor and adductor muscles overpowering the extensors and abductors.
    • The hip adopts a position of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.
    • The adduction deformity causes the pelvis to tilt upwards, making the affected limb appear shorter (apparent shortening), though true limb lengths remain equal.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Internal rotation is evident.
    • Also referred to as the stage of apparent shortening.

Stage III: Stage of Erosion

  • Key Features:
    • Destruction of the cartilage and erosion of the head of the femur and/or acetabulum.
    • Possible pathological dislocation or subluxation of the hip.
    • The position of the limb remains in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation, but the deformities are exaggerated.
    • There is true shortening of the limb due to actual bone destruction, alongside further apparent shortening caused by the adduction deformity.

Option A and C - Apparent lengthening is not seen in Perthes disease or neglected DDH instead both will have true shortening.

Option D: There is true shortening of the limb due to actual bone destruction, alongside further apparent shortening caused by the adduction deformity.

Key takeaways

There is generally a true shortening in TB of the hip, except in Stage I, in which an apparent lengthening occurs. Limb length discrepancy can occur at this joint not only because of actual shortening of the bones (true length) but also because of the adduction-abduction deformity, which results in pelvic tilt and thus affects the length of the limb (apparent length).

choices.text: All of these are preferred options

questions.text: A 44 yr carpenter presents with adduction deformity and arthritis in right hip with true shortening of 2cm in right lower limb. He had a past history of TB hip for which he has taken full course of ATT 5 yrs back. His family is dependent on him financially. Least preferred treatment option for him will be:
questions.solution:
Treatment for TB of the Hip

Objectives:

  • Control disease activity.
  • Preserve joint movement.

Early Stages (Stages I and II):

  • Conservative Treatment:
    • Antitubercular Chemotherapy: As per standard regimens.
    • Care of the Hip:
      • Immobilization: Below-knee skin traction for rest and pain relief.
      • General Care: Follow specific guidelines.

Later Stages (Stage III and beyond):

  • Operative Treatment:
    1. Joint Debridement:
      • Remove pus, necrotic tissue, and dead cartilage.
      • Post-op: Traction and joint mobilization.
    2. Girdlestone Arthroplasty:
      • Excise the head and neck of the femur.
      • Post-op: Skeletal traction followed by hip mobilization.
    3. Arthrodesis:
      • Fuse the hip joint if a stiff hip in a functional position is preferred.
    4. Corrective Osteotomy:
      • Subtrochanteric osteotomy for unacceptable bony ankylosis positions.
    5. Total Hip Replacement:
      • Effective for quiescent TB; alternative in cost-sensitive regions is excision arthroplasty.

Option A - Arthrodesis was previously done where the patient needs stability and can compromise on mobility but it is difficult to carry out day to day activities and hence not preferred these days.

Option B - If infection is quiescent >>>>> patient needs mobility >>>>>  Girdlestone arthroplasty (unaffordable)

Option C - If infection is quiescent >>>>>patient needs mobility >>>>> THR (if affordable)

Key takeaways:

  • If infection is active without arthritis >>>>> Debridement + ATT
  • If infection is active with arthritis >>>>>> Girdlestone arthroplasty + ATT

questions.text: A gardener sustained a thorn prick injury for 4 days and now presents with a felon over the pulp of index finger. He was advised to do surgical I&D of the pus but he denies surgery. All of these are possible complications of felon except:
questions.solution:
Terminal Pulp Space Infection (Whitlow or Felon)

Surgical Anatomy:

  • Location: Volar space of the distal digit, filled with compact fat and divided by fibrous septae.
  • Proximal Closure: Septum of deep fascia connects the distal flexor crease to the periosteum just distal to the profundus flexor tendon insertion.
  • Digital Artery: Gives a branch to the epiphysis before entering the space and then divides into terminal branches.

Clinical Features:

  • Common Cause: Often results from a pin-prick.
  • Affected Digits: Index finger and thumb most frequently.
  • Symptoms:
    • Swelling, tenderness, and tense pulp.
    • Severe throbbing pain and excruciating tenderness suggest suppuration.

Treatment:

  • Early Stage: Conservative treatment to abort infection.
  • Later Stage: Requires drainage:
    • Incision directly over the abscess center or a lateral incision in front of the terminal phalanx plane.

Key takeaways -

Complications related to untreated/ delayed treatment in felon are:

  • Osteomyelitis of the terminal phalanx (Option B)
  • Necrosis and sequestration of terminal half of distal phalanx
  • Pyogenic arthritis of the DIP joint (Option A)
  • Suppurative tenosynovitis (rare) (Option D)

choices.text: Flexion, anterior subluxation and external rotation
Flexion, posterior subluxation and internal rotation
Flexion, posterior subluxation and external rotation
Extension, posterior subluxation and external rotation

questions.text: Triple deformity of knee typically seen in advanced TB knee consists of following components:
questions.solution:
Pathology of Tuberculosis of the Knee

Disease Origin:

  • Osseous Tuberculosis:
    • Location: Typically begins in the femoral or tibial condyles; less commonly in the patella.
    • Description: Initial infection starts in the bone.
  • Synovial Tuberculosis:
    • Location: More commonly begins in the synovial membrane.
    • Description: Leads to hypertrophy (enlargement) of the synovium.

Natural History:

  • Early Stages:
    • The disease may be confined to the synovium.
    • Synovial hypertrophy occurs without significant joint damage.
    • Inflammation primarily affects the synovial membrane.
  • Later Stages:
    • Destruction of Articular Cartilage and Bone:
      • The disease progresses to destroy both cartilage and underlying bone.
      • The hypertrophied synovium spreads over and under the cartilage, leading to its destruction.
      • Cartilage detachment exposes the bone.
    • Joint Distension and Subluxation:
      • Prolonged Joint Distension: Due to synovial effusion and pus formation.
      • Destruction of Ligaments: Leads to subluxation of the tibia.
        • The tibia may flex, slip backward, and rotate externally on the femoral condyles (known as triple subluxation).
      • Formation of Abscesses:
        • Pus Formation: Pus may burst out of the joint capsule, resulting in a cold abscess.
        • Sinus Formation: The abscess may eventually lead to the development of a sinus.

Healing:

  • Fibrous Healing:
    • Untreated: The body's attempt to heal can result in fibrosis.
    • Fibrous Ankylosis: The joint becomes stiff and fixed in a deformed position due to the formation of fibrous tissue.

Key takeaways :

  • Long standing distension of the joint and destruction of the ligaments produces subluxation of the tibia. The tibia flexes, slips backwards and rotates externally on the femoral condyles (triple subluxation). (Option A,B, C and D)

questions.text: A pediatrician referred a 3 yr old malnourished child to an orthopaedician with complaints of lethargy, swollen wrists and following xray. Which radiological finding is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Radiological features of rickets include following-

  • Early radiological changes are observed in the lower ends of the radius and ulna. X-rays of both wrists and knees - antero-posterior views are used for screening a patient suspected of rickets.
  • Delayed appearance of epiphyses.
  • Widening of the epiphyseal plates
  • Cupping of the metaphysis
  • Splaying of the metaphysis
  • Bone deformities: Knock knees, bow legs and coxa vara are common deformities in older children.

Option A,B and C - Splaying of the metaphysis, Widening of the epiphyseal plates and bow legs (genu varum) are all seen in patients of rickets.

Option D - White line of Frankel is classically seen in scurvy patients.

Key Takeaway -

Radiological features of Rickets:

  • Cupping & Splaying of metaphysis
  • Widened Epiphysis
  • Genu Varum, Coxa Vara

questions.text: A 49 yr old patient presented with severe pain and deformity of the right hip. X Ray showed severe arthritis of right hip and hence he was advised total hip replacement. During the surgery the femoral head cartilage was found as follows. Which metabolic product leads to this condition:
questions.solution:
Alkaptonuria Arthritis (Ochronosis)

  • Cause:
    • Inherited defect in the enzyme system responsible for the metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine.
    • Unable to do the excretion of homogentisic acid in the urine. (Option C)
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Homogentisic acid accumulates in cartilage and connective tissues.
    • Results in black/brown discolouration of affected tissues.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Onset: Joint symptoms typically occur after age 40.
    • Commonly Affected Joints: Spine and shoulder joints.
    • Pigment Deposits: Possible pigment deposit in the sclera.
    • Urine: Dark brown color due to oxidation of homogentisic acid when exposed to air.
  • Radiological Findings:
    • X-ray: Disc space calcification and periarticular calcification in large joints ultimately leading to arthritis.
  • Treatment:
    • Same as for osteoarthritis.

Option A - Uric acid deposition results in gout

Option B - Pyrophosphoric acid deposition results in pseudogout.

Option D - Not applicable.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with severe pain and deformity in hands and fingers. X Rays of hand shows typical pencil-in-cup type of deformity in DIP. Probable diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic Arthropathy

  • Prevalence: Affects 5%-30% of patients with psoriasis.
  • Onset: Typically, skin disease precedes arthritis.
  • Demographics: Equally affects men and women, usually between 30-40 years of age.

Key Clinical Features:

  • Joint Involvement:
    • Characteristic involvement of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints (rare in other inflammatory arthritis).
  • Nail Changes (in 90% of cases):
    • Pitting, fragmentation, and discoloration.
  • Dactylitis ("Sausage Digits"): Seen in 30% of cases.
  • Enthesitis and Tenosynovitis: Prominent features.
  • Arthritis Mutilans:
    • The most destructive form, causing telescoping (shortening) of digits.

Pathophysiology:

  • Upregulated RANK-L expression in synovium (B-type cells).
  • Marked increase in osteoclast precursors leading to bone erosion.

Radiographic Findings:

  • Pencil-in-Cup Deformity: Typically seen in the DIP joints.
  • Small Joint Ankylosis: Fusion of joints.
  • Osteolysis: Destruction of metacarpal (MC) and phalangeal bones.
  • Periostitis and Bony Enthesitis: Inflammation and bone formation at tendon attachment sites.

Diagnosis:

  • Classic skin lesions of psoriasis aid in diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Steroids are commonly used for managing symptoms.

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis Spare Distal DIP Joints.

Pencil in cup deformity is typical for Psoriatic arthritis.

Option C: Haemophilia most commonly involves Knee and other large joints.

Option D: Neuropathic Arthritis typically shows total destruction of foot and ankle joints.

Key Takeaway -

Presentation of psoriatic arthritis is like rheumatoid arthritis - a polyarthritis, distal IP joints of hands involved (unlike rheumatoid arthritis, where these are spared). Classic skin and nail lesions help in diagnosis. Rheumatoid factor is negative. Treatment is by steroids.

questions.text: A physician refers a 44 yr female with clinical diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism after relevant investigation to an orthopedician for complaints of multiple bone pains especially in hands, anorexia and abdominal cramps. All of these can be seen in her x rays except:
questions.solution:
Hyperparathyroid

X-Ray Examination in Hyperparathyroidism

  1. General Features:
    • Irregular, Diffuse Rarefaction: Bones appear less dense and irregularly porous.
  2. Specific Signs:
    • Salt and Pepper Appearance (Option A)
      • Description: Skull bones exhibit stippling with small opaque areas resembling salt and pepper.
    • Loss of Lamina Dura:
      • Description: The lamina dura, a thin white line surrounding the teeth, is absorbed, leading to loss of cortical bone.
    • Subperiosteal Resorption (Option D):
      • Description: Resorption of phalanges and possibly the lateral end of the clavicle.
    • Spinal Changes:
      • Description: Central collapse of vertebral bodies and biconvex intervertebral discs.
    • Pelvis and Other Bones:
      • Description: Coarse striations with cyst-like spaces visible on X-ray.
    • Brown's Tumour (Option B):
      • Description: Expansile lytic bone lesion resembling a tumor, typically affecting the maxilla or mandible.
    • Extra-Osseous Features:
      • Description: Possible presence of renal calculi and other features.

Option A, B & D: Salt & Pepper Appearance, Brown's Tumor and Subperiosteal resorption all three are seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Option C: Frontal Bossing is Typically seen in rickets, not hyperparathyroidism.

Key Takeaway -

Brown's Tumour (Osteitis Fibrosa Cystica) is A lytic bone lesion associated with hyperparathyroidism, appearing as expansile, cyst-like areas. Caused by elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) leading to increased bone resorption and fibrous tissue replacement. Typically in the maxilla, mandible, and can also affect long bones and vertebrae.

questions.text: Fluorosis occurs due to excessive deposition of fluoride in bone and soft tissues. Earliest sign of fluorosis is.................... ?
questions.solution:
Fluorosis:

Types:

  1. Dental Fluorosis:
    • Description: Early sign, characterized by erosion of enamel. (Option B)
    • Common Site: Usually seen in the upper incisors.
  2. Skeletal Fluorosis:
    • Description: Advanced condition leading to:
      • Spine stiffness (Option C)
      • Paraesthesia (tingling or numbness) (Option D)
      • Osteosclerosis (Option A)
      • Spastic paraparesis (muscle weakness in the lower limbs)
      • Inter osseous membrance calcification

Diagnosis: X-rays may show changes in bone density and structure in skeletal fluorosis.

Option A, C & D: Skeletal Fluorosis Present with Paresthesia, Spine Stiffness & Osteosclerosis which are seen in the late phase.

Key Takeaway:

Earliest sign of fluorosis Is Mottling of Teeth seen in upper incisors. Advanced Skeletal Fluorosis Present with Paresthesia, Spine Stiffness & Osteosclerosis.

questions.text: A 39 yr old male patient presents with non traumatic wrist pain, with an osteolytic area over distal radius on xray. Serum evaluation reveals high Ca, low phosphate and elevated ALP. Probable diagnosis would be?
questions.solution:
Primary Hyperparathyroidism

Definition:

  • Excessive parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion from the parathyroid glands, leading to high serum calcium levels.

Causes:

  • Parathyroid adenoma (most common)
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia
  • Parathyroid carcinoma (rare)

Pathophysiology:

  • Increased PTH causes elevated serum calcium through enhanced bone resorption, intestinal absorption, and renal reabsorption.

Clinical Features:

  • Bone: Osteoporosis, fractures
  • Renal: Kidney stones
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, abdominal pain
  • Neurological: Fatigue, depression

Diagnostic Markers:

  • Elevated PTH
  • Elevated serum calcium
  • Normal or low serum phosphorus
  • Elevated ALP

Imaging:

  • Ultrasound or sestamibi scan to locate parathyroid adenoma.

Management:

  • Surgical: Parathyroidectomy
  • Medical: Bisphosphonates, calcimimetics
  • Lifestyle: Adequate hydration, monitoring calcium levels

Prognosis:

  • Generally favourable with treatment, especially when managed early.

Option A: Calcium and phosphate are normal in Paget's disease but ALP is markedly elevated.

Option B: In renal osteodystrophy, calcium is normal/low, phosphate is low and ALP is high.

Option C: In secondary hyperparathyroidism -ca low/normal, phosphate is increase,ALP increased.

Key Takeaway -

  • Brown's tumor is an expansile bone lesion, a collection of osteoclasts. It commonly affects the maxilla or mandible, though any bone may be affected. Serum calcium is high, phosphates low and alkaline phosphatase high. All these are features of primary hyperparathyroidism.
